Fig 6 Research Paper Photoredox-promoted co-production of 3,4-dihydroisoquinoline and H2 over Pd-doped leaf-like CdS catalyst Yu Chen Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Validation Investigation Formal analysis a Ming-Yu Qi Writing – review & editing Validation b Zi-Rong Tang Writing – review & editing Supervision Resources Project administration Funding acquisition Conceptualization a ⁎ a College of Chemistry, State Key Laboratory of Photocatalysis on Energy and Environment, Fuzhou University, Fuzhou, 350116, PR China College of Chemistry State Key Laboratory of Photocatalysis on Energy and Environment Fuzhou University Fuzhou 350116 PR China aCollege of Chemistry, State Key Laboratory of Photocatalysis on Energy and Environment, Fuzhou University, Fuzhou, 350116, PR China b Institute of Fundamental and Frontier Sciences, University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, Chengdu, 611731, PR China Institute of Fundamental and Frontier Sciences University of Electronic Science and Technology of China Chengdu 611731 PR China bInstitute of Fundamental and Frontier Sciences, University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, Chengdu, 611731, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Integrating selective organic transformation and hydrogen (H2) evolution in one photoredox reaction system is one of the most sustainable and promising approaches to efficiently produce solar fuels and chemicals by simultaneously utilizing photogenerated electrons and holes. Herein, through the cation-exchange engineering method, the nanoleaf-like Pd/CdS composites are gingerly fabricated for visible-light-driven receptor-free dehydrogenation of 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinoline (THIQ) to 3,4-dihydroisoquinoline (DHIQ) and H2 under ambient conditions. The optimized electronic structure endows Pd/CdS with a narrow band gap and suitable energy band positions, thus facilitating the light harvesting as well as the separation and transfer of photoexcited charge carriers. Consequently, the Pd/CdS exhibits significantly improved photoredox activity compared to bare CdS. In-situ Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy and electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy track the progression of reaction intermediates during such a dual-functional photoredox-catalyzed system, revealing that the carbon-centered radical is the key reaction intermediate in this reaction process. It is anticipated that this work would guide the rational utilization of CdS-based materials to enable simultaneous photochemical coupling of organic transformation and H2 evolution. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Redox coupling photocatalysis H2 evolution 3,4-Dihydroisoquinoline production Pd doping CdS-based materials Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With the rapid development of global industrialization and urbanization, the energy crisis and environmental pollution have emerged as two major problems in the world [1–9]. Hydrogen (H2), as the cleanest fuel and energy source that can realize no greenhouse gas cycle, has attracted ever-increasing attention for its remarkable commercial worth and exceptional volumetric energy density, and diverse applications across numerous industries, encompassing petrochemical, electronic industries, fuel cells, metal smelting, etc. [10,11]. On the other hand, 3,4-dihydroisoquinoline (DHIQ) is an economically valuable intermediate in the pharmaceutical synthesis and pharmaceutical industry [12,13], and its synthesis has inspired the continuous efforts of academic and industrial scientists. Traditionally, the production of DHIQ requires the setting of extreme conditions or the participation of toxic reagents, suffering from increased costs [14], cumbersome operation steps [15], low selectivity [16], and environmental destruction [17]. Therefore, it is of great benefit to develop a green and efficient synthesis scheme. In this context, acceptor-free photocatalytic dehydrogenation has developed rapidly not only because of its eco-friendly and sustainable feature for the synthesis of high-value-added organic compounds, but also due to its enormous potentials for H2 transportation and storage [18–20]. Therefore, it is a promising strategy to realize the co-production of DHIQ and H2 in one photoredox process. Cadmium sulfide (CdS), a classical and essential semiconductor of the IIB-VIB groups [21], has been extensively investigated in photocatalysis owing to its narrow bandgap of approximately 2.4 eV and adequate negative conduction band (CB) position [22], which satisfies the potential requirements of most photocatalytic reactions [23]. However, the photocatalytic performance of single CdS is unavoidably limited by its inherent drawbacks such as the high recombination rate of electron-hole pairs and the absence of functional active sites toward specific reactants [24]. In this regard, the cation-exchange engineering method provides an efficient approach to surmount these hurdles [25,26], via the introduction of the heteroatoms as catalytically active sites for target reactant and the doping-related energy levels to optimize the energy band structure of a semiconductor photocatalyst [27–30]. Additionally, it has been well organized that the two-dimensional (2D) structure of CdS has the structural advantages for shortening the migration distance of photogenerated charge carriers, increasing the specific surface area, and exposing the active sites on an open 2D platform [31,32]. Herein, we report the synthesis of Pd-doped 2D leaf-like CdS nanosheets through the cation-exchange approach, which can be used as a dual-functional photoredox catalyst toward the visible-light-driven dehydrogenation of 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinoline (THIQ) to DHIQ and H2 under ambient conditions. The ingenious Pd cation-exchange strategy can effectively optimize the electronic structure of CdS as well as increase active sites for H2 evolution, which results in the enhanced light harvesting ability and accelerated photoexcited electron-hole pairs separation, thereby promoting the photocatalytic performance of Pd/CdS compared with bare CdS. The reaction mechanism of this dual-functional photoredox reaction has been revealed by the joint in-situ Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy, electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy, and controllable contrast experiments. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Thiourea (CH4N2S), hydrofluoric acid (HF, 40 wt%), palladium nitrate dihydrate (Pd(NO3)2·2H2O, Pd ≥ 39.0 %), acetonitrile (CH3CN, MeCN), triethanolamine (C6H15NO3, TEOA), carbon tetrachloride (CCl4), anhydrous methanol (CH3OH, MeOH), and anhydrous ethanol (C2H6O) were procured from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., Shanghai, China. Cadmium acetate dihydrate (Cd(CH3COO)2·2H2O), 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinoline (C9H11N, THIQ), 3,4-dihydroisoquinoline (C9H9N, DHIQ), and isoquinoline (C9H7N, IQ) were obtained from Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co. Ltd., Shanghai, China. All materials were used as received. Deionized (DI) water was sourced locally. 2.2 Synthesis 2.2.1 Synthesis of the leaf-like CdS nanosheets The synthesis of the leaf-like CdS nanosheets was accomplished by a hydrothermal process [31]. Details of the process are provided in the supporting materials. 2.2.2 Synthesis of the Pd-doped leaf-like CdS composites The Pd-doped leaf-like CdS composites were synthesized by a simple cation exchange technique [33]. Specifically, 50 mg of the as-prepared leaf-like CdS nanosheets were dispersed in 90 mL of aqueous methanol solution (the volume ratio of MeOH to DI was 2:1). After sonication of the above suspension for 5 min, a certain amount of Pd(NO3)2·2H2O solution was pipetted and quickly injected into the above suspension. After stirring at room temperature for 60 min, the sample was filtered and washed. Lastly, the samples were dried overnight in a vacuum oven maintained at 60 °C. The obtained composite sample is marked as Pd x /CdS (x represents the theoretical mass ratio of doped Pd, x = 0.04 %, 0.08 %, 0.24 %, 0.40 %, and 0.56 %.). 2.3 Photoactivity experiment The photocatalytic performance tests were performed on the basis of previous studies with a few adjustments [34]. In a quintessential process, 10 mL of MeCN, 10 mg of as-synthesized Pd/CdS, and 100 μmol of THIQ were added into the quartz reactor with a double layer. The reactor was purged with argon (Ar) for 15 min prior to light exposure to completely remove air. Then, a 300 W Xe lamp (CEL-HXF300-T3, China Education Au-light Co., Ltd., Beijing, China) was employed to irradiate the suspension under visible light (λ > 420 nm) for 2 h. Eventually, it is connected to circulating condensate for this system. The generated H2 and liquid products were quantitatively and qualitatively examined using the gas chromatograph (GC-8A 2014C of Shimadzu, column of MS-5A) and the gas chromatograph-mass spectrometer (GC–MS QP 2020 of Shimadzu, Q-Exactive), respectively. 3 Results and discussion As demonstrated in Fig. 1 a, a series of two-dimensional (2D) leaf-like Pd/CdS photocatalysts have been successfully prepared by the joint hydrothermal process and cation-exchange method (unless otherwise stated, the characterizations presented hereinafter primarily revolve around the 0.24 wt% Pd/CdS, since it shows the best photoredox activity.). Details of the material morphology have been confirmed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). As plotted in Figs. 1 b,c and S1a,b, the pristine CdS and Pd/CdS show a hexagonal leaf-like structure with a distinct main stem and highly ordered branches distributed on both sides of the main stem, and the size of their leaf-like ranges from 4 to 6 μm. Both of those materials consist of several 2D parallel multilayer structures with smooth surfaces. These unique 2D leaf-like morphologies not only enable the exposure of the open surface active site, but also beneficially shorten the longitudinal transmission distance of the photogenerated excitons [31,32]. The corresponding fast Fourier transform (FFT) analysis (Fig. 1 d and S1e) and inversing FFT analysis (Fig. 1 e and S1f) have been conducted to determine the crystal facets of the bare CdS and Pd/CdS. The measured lattice spacing of both CdS and Pd/CdS can be indexed to the (002) crystal facet of hexagonal CdS (Fig. S1g and S2) [35], illustrating that the Pd doping has no apparent influence on the crystalline phase of the hexagonal CdS. The high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS) mapping results demonstrate a homogeneous distribution of the Pd element while maintaining the anionic framework virtually unchanged (Fig. 1 f) [36], which explicitly confirms the successful doping of Pd into the leaf-like CdS nanosheets. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) has been equipped to study the valence states and chemical compositions of the elements in the relevant samples. All elements related to Pd/CdS can be determined in the survey spectra (Fig. 2 a), which are well-matched with the EDS mapping results. The binding energies of Cd 3d in Fig. 2 b demonstrate that the spin-orbit doublet peaks at 405.28 eV and 412.08 eV are indexed to Cd 3d5/2 and Cd 3d3/2, respectively, which match well with the Cd2+ of CdS [37,38]. The peaks at 161.68 eV and 162.88 eV in the high-resolution S 2p XPS spectrum in Fig. 2 c are classified as S 2p3/2 and S 2p1/2, respectively, which can be relevant to S2− in Pd/CdS [39]. As for Pd 3d in Pd/CdS, the peaks at 336.78 eV and 342.18 eV index to the binding energies of Pd 3d5/2 and Pd 3d3/2 (Fig. 2 d), which are relevant to the Pd2+ [40]. Of note, with the doping of Pd, the peaks of the characteristic relevant to Cd 3d and S 2p associated with the 2D leaf-like Pd/CdS composites have a slight blue shift, which demonstrates the strong electronic interaction between CdS and Pd dopant [41,42]. Subsequently, the related samples have been analyzed by UV/Vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) to study their optical absorption properties. As shown in Fig. 2 e, all samples exhibit comparable absorption band edges at Ca. 510 nm, which arise from the inherent bandgap photoexcitation of the CdS [43]. Remarkably, the light absorption of all samples is significantly enhanced with increasing Pd doping amount. Furthermore, X-ray diffraction (XRD) spectroscopy has been applied to determine the crystal phase structure of the above materials. As demonstrated in Fig. 2 f, the characteristic diffraction peaks of CdS at 24.9°, 26.5°, and 28.3° are indexed to the (100), (002), and (101) crystalline planes of the hexagonal CdS (JCPDS No. 06-314) [32], respectively. The leaf-like Pd/CdS nanosheets with different Pd doping amounts have almost the same XRD spectra as that of pure CdS, and no obvious diffraction peaks associated with Pd are monitored due to the small amount of doping and the uniform distribution of Pd dopant [44]. The photocatalytic activity of bare CdS and Pd x /CdS (x = 0.04 %, 0.08 %, 0.24 %, 0.40 %, and 0.56 %) has been tested by the dual-functional photoredox system of coupling H2 evolution and selective conversion of 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinoline (THIQ) to 3,4-dihydroisoquinoline (DHIQ) under visible light (λ > 420 nm) illumination (Fig. 3 a). Gas and liquid products have been characterized and quantified by gas chromatography (GC) and gas chromatography-mass (GC–MS) spectrometry (Fig. S3), respectively. As sketched in Fig. 3 b, the efficiency of the bare CdS for dehydrogenation conversion of THIQ is extremely low, and the production rates of H2 and DHIQ are 20.9 and 173.1 μmol g–1 h–1, respectively, within 2 h of visible-light exposure. The doping of Pd effectively enhances the catalytic performance of CdS, and a volcano-like trend is observed between the doping amount and the photocatalytic activity. The best catalytic activity is exhibited by Pd(0.24 %)/CdS, with the production rates of 1913.8 and 1885.9 μmol g–1 h–1 for H2 and DHIQ, respectively, which are 91.6 and 10.9 times higher than those of blank CdS, respectively. Moreover, this dual-functional photocatalytic system has excellent selectivity for the DHIQ. The molar ratio of the generated H2 and organic compounds is calculated to be Ca. 1.0, demonstrating a stoichiometric photoredox dehydrogenative reaction [39]. From the experimental results of the time curve in Fig. 3 c, the conversion of THIQ over Pd/CdS composite increases with light irradiation time, and the conversion of THIQ reaches more than 93.5 % within 18 h. It is noteworthy that further dehydrogenation of DHIQ to generate isoquinoline (IQ) is theoretically considered to be an automatic procedure owing to the aromatization of the molecular structure [45]. However, the production of IQ consistently remains at a fairly low level (Ca. 10.1 μmol within 18 h), suggesting that the process of DHIQ overoxidation to IQ is rather slow [46]. As displayed in Fig. 3 d, the yields of DHIQ over Pd/CdS under different monochromatic light irradiations depend on the wavelength of the incident light and match well with the DRS spectra of the Pd/CdS samples, which suggests that the photoredox reaction is driven by photoexcitation of CdS. The reusability experiments and time profiles have been carried out to benchmark the stability of the Pd/CdS samples. As can be seen in Fig. 3 e, no obvious decrease in photocatalytic activity is noted after five cycles in 10 h, revealing the excellent catalytic stability and recyclability of Pd/CdS. Moreover, the crystal structure of Pd/CdS exhibits minimal changes after the recycle tests, which further demonstrates its excellent stability in the photoredox-catalyzed dehydrogenation reaction of THIQ (Fig. S4). With the purpose of unraveling the reasons for the enhanced photoactivity of Pd/CdS, a comprehensive suite of electrochemical, photoelectrochemical, photoluminescence (PL), and time-resolved photoluminescence (TRPL) measurements have been taken to investigate the light-induced electron-hole pairs separation and transfer capacity of those samples [47]. From the linear scanning voltammetry (LSV) test results (Fig. 4 a), the Pd/CdS possesses a higher current density than the blank CdS over similar potential ranges, which indicates that the Pd/CdS exhibits higher electrochemical H2 evolution performance [48]. Transient photocurrent-time (I-t) tests have been used to probe the photoinduced carrier separation efficiency of the bare CdS and Pd/CdS. The Pd/CdS samples exhibit higher photocurrent densities compared to blank CdS (Fig. 4 b), demonstrating a higher charge carrier separation efficiency over Pd/CdS [49]. As demonstrated in Fig. 4 c, the resistance between Pd/CdS and the electrolyte is lower than that of CdS, which can be confirmed by the narrower semicircle in the Nyquist frequency plot, suggesting that Pd/CdS possesses a higher charge transfer efficiency than CdS [50]. And this distinctly improved charge transfer over Pd/CdS has also been confirmed by the cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves (Fig. 4 d). As plotted in Fig. 4 e, the intensity of the PL emission peak of Pd/CdS (∼542 nm) is rather weaker than that of blank CdS, verifying that the recombination of photogenerated carriers is effectively suppressed in Pd/CdS samples. Furthermore, the dynamics of photo-induced carrier transfer have been examined by TRPL tests. The average decay lifetime (τa) calculated from the exponential decay kinetic function is usually utilized to depict the group emission decay behavior of the photocatalyst. In general, a smaller average decay lifetime of the sample indicates a higher separation efficiency of its photogenerated carriers [51]. As displayed in Fig. 4 f and Table S1, the τa value of the Pd/CdS (7.61 ns) is smaller than that of the blank CdS (10.38 ns), which indicates that the interfacial carrier migration of Pd/CdS is faster. For an in-depth study of the mechanism of this dual-functional reaction system, a series of control and quenching experiments have been performed. As shown in Fig. 5 a, in a setup without light or photocatalyst, the production of H2 and DHIQ is barely detectable (entries B and C), which suggests that light and photocatalyst are indispensable in this reaction process. The generation of DHIQ is severely hindered after the addition of the TEOA (a hole scavenger) to the system, while the H2 evolution is almost undetectable after the addition of the CCl4 (an electronic scavenger). Those results indicate that both electrons and holes play a role in the reaction process (entries D and E). After adding the 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline N-oxide (DMPO) to the photoredox catalytic system to trap the active species, the production of both H2 and DHIQ decreased, indicating that free radicals are the active intermediates driving the formation of those target products. (entry F) [52]. In addition, for determining the active intermediates of the system, electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopy using DMPO as the intermediate capture reagent has been performed. As sketched in Fig. 5 b and c, under the illumination, sextet signal peaks (hydrogen overclocking splitting of αH = 22.29 G and nitrogen overclocking splitting of αN = 15.84 G) are observed in the related materials, suggesting the existence of central carbon radical reactive species (•CH(NH)C8H8) in this system [45,46]. Remarkably, the EPR signal intensity of Pd/CdS is significantly powerful compared with the pristine CdS (Fig. 5 c), which is consistent with the photocatalytic performance, suggesting that the doping of Pd facilitates the forming of •CH(NH)C8H8 species. Subsequently, for the further revelation of the reaction mechanism, the in-situ Fourier transform-infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy has been equipped to explore the changing progression of reacting species during the photoredox catalyzing reaction. As demonstrated in the in-situ FT-IR spectrum of Pd/CdS (Fig. 5 d), the peaks at 3257 and 3349 cm–1 corresponding to the stretching vibration of the N–H bond in the THIQ [53], and the decreasing intensity of these peaks indicates that THIQ is consumed under visible light illumination. Notably, a progressively stronger peak is detected at 1629 cm–1 as the photocatalytic reaction proceeds, which can be classified as the C=N bond in DHIQ [54], signifying the generation of DHIQ. The energy band structure of a semiconductor determines the redox capacity of photogenerated carriers, which in turn affects its photocatalytic performance. Based on the Kubelka-Munk functions obtained from the DRS spectral transformations of the relevant samples (Fig. S5) [55], the bandgap (Eg) over bare CdS has been determined to be 2.41 eV (Pd/CdS for 2.35 eV). The reduced Eg facilitates the light-harvesting ability of the composites. In addition, depending on the Mott-Schottky plots (Fig. S6) [53], the conduction band (CB) position is –0.75 V vs. normal hydrogen electrode (NHE) for Pd/CdS, which indicates that the proton reduction potential is more favorable than that of the pristine CdS (–0.64 V vs. NHE). Furthermore, Pd, as a platinum group element, can serve as the active sites for H2 evolution [56]. The valence band (VB) energy level of CdS and Pd/CdS have been determinable from the equation EVB = ECB + Eg as 1.77 and 1.60 V vs. NHE, respectively. The redshift of VB further impedes the secondary dehydrogenation process of the reaction and improves the selectivity of DHIQ [12]. With the above analysis, a reasonable reaction mechanism of the co-production of DHIQ and H2 by THIQ semi-dehydrogenation over 2D leaf-like Pd/CdS has been proposed (Fig. 6 ). Under visible light exposure, the electron-hole pairs are excited from Pd/CdS. The doped Pd species effectively separate photoexcited carriers by trapping photoexcited electrons, and supply active sites for H2 evolution, and the unique 2D leaf-like morphology of Pd/CdS dramatically shortens the migration distance of photoexcited electron-hole pairs to the photocatalyst surface. Subsequently, the THIQ adsorbed on the CdS surface is attacked by the photogenerated hole to generate radical cation intermediate (CH(NH+•)C8H8), which then deprotonated to form the carbon radical intermediate (•CH(NH)C8H8) [13]. The •CH(NH)C8H8 intermediate is further attacked by the photogenerated hole to remove another proton, eventually forming the semi-dehydrogenated product of DHIQ. Meanwhile, protons extracted from THIQ interact with photogenerated electrons gathered on the Pd species for H2 evolution. Although the isomers of DHIQ can generate fully deprotonated IQ by a second dehydrogenation process, this process is thermodynamically unfavorable due to the lower positive valence band potential of CdS [57]. 4 Conclusion In summary, an ingenious cation-exchange engineering has been reported for the construction of 2D leaf-like Pd/CdS composites toward a dual-functional photoredox reaction of dehydrogenation of THIQ into DHIQ and H2 production. Compared with pure CdS, the Pd exchange strategy ameliorates the electronic structure of the photocatalyst, which in turn enhances the light-harvesting ability, accelerates the separation of photogenerated carriers, and optimizes the photoredox ability, thereby significantly improving the photocatalytic efficiency of the Pd/CdS. In addition, mechanistic explorations have demonstrated that carbon-centered radical intermediate (•CH(NH)C8H8) plays an essential role in this photocatalytic oxidation process, and the doping of Pd species promotes the formation of •CH(NH)C8H8. This work is expected to provide a rational scheme for the design of advanced semiconductor photocatalysts for efficient H2 fuel production and organic synthesis. coredata.dc:description: Integrating selective organic transformation and hydrogen (H2) evolution in one photoredox reaction system is one of the most sustainable and promising approaches to efficiently produce solar fuels and chemicals by simultaneously utilizing photogenerated electrons and holes. Herein, through the cation-exchange engineering method, the nanoleaf-like Pd/CdS composites are gingerly fabricated for visible-light-driven receptor-free dehydrogenation of 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinoline (THIQ) to 3,4-dihydroisoquinoline (DHIQ) and H2 under ambient conditions. The optimized electronic structure endows Pd/CdS with a narrow band gap and suitable energy band positions, thus facilitating the light harvesting as well as the separation and transfer of photoexcited charge carriers. Consequently, the Pd/CdS exhibits significantly improved photoredox activity compared to bare CdS. In-situ Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy and electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy track the progression of reaction intermediates during such a dual-functional photoredox-catalyzed system, revealing that the carbon-centered radical is the key reaction intermediate in this reaction process. It is anticipated that this work would guide the rational utilization of CdS-based materials to enable simultaneous photochemical coupling of organic transformation and H2 evolution.
coredata.dc:title: Photoredox-promoted co-production of 3,4-dihydroisoquinoline and H2 over Pd-doped leaf-like CdS catalyst
